narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: monthly mandatory office hour attendance
n/a
None
The class was held in a virtual writing workshop format (with some supplementary lectures by the instructor).

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My fiction writing skills improved
Exposure to excellent selection of short stories, learned how to revise/think critically about my own writing (and others' writing), practiced a variety of techniques for more persuasive storytelling

I was able to develop my writing skills through weekly exercises and two long, revised stories. There were two workshops held for each of the long stories, and while student feedback was generally mediocre, Prof. Gaige provided a lot of one-on-one support. Prof. Gaige also provided an interesting variety of course readings, which were helpful.
I learned so much about how to write clearly and persuasively and honestly.

I learned how to write persuasive fiction, use unreliable narrators (first and third person), and use form as a mechanism of content, expanding  time and space deliberately for (de)emphasis. I worked on writing stories that are both imbued with an underlying theme or aboutness without encroaching on the readers ability to make meaning of the text themselves.

You really learn how to write a literary short story well. Emphasis on *literary short story*. This is not necessarily where you will learn how to write the next Hunger Games or Stephen King novel. It's for the people who want to write the next "The Lottery" or "Harrison Bergeron".
I practiced and developed my fiction writing and critical analysis skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was great. I enjoy the workshop format because you can come away with great feedback from your peers. More feedback from the instructor however would have been great, but I think that entirely depends on which professor you have

I loved this course. The workshops were definitely a strength of this course. Professor Gaige created a warm, respectful, and productive learning environment in which to praise and critique each other's writing, discuss what makes for persuasive storytelling, analyze exemplary works of short fiction, and collaboratively grapple with some of the literary/personal challenges that confront writers. I learned so much about my strengths and weaknesses of my writing through the workshop, and through Professor Gaige's super helpful office hour sessions. I really enjoyed the fun short exercises, which helped to ease us into the two longer writing assignments; they also helped to hone particular aspects of our writing, like prose rhythm, narration, etc. The short stories that Professor Gaige selected for our reading and analysis were also really enjoyable.

I think the weekly exercises provided for good engagement on a variety of fiction techniques. However, I didn't feel adequately prepared to write the final story, which was meant to be 12-20 pages long. I wonder if there was a way to reduce the amount of in-class time spent workshopping so that the professor could lecture more.

I loved the course. I learned so much and Professor Gaige was amazing. One thing that I think could be improved is the structure of the course. We started the first week with a writing assignment, but I think it might be better to spend the first week or two doing tons of reading of different fiction pieces and then discussing them a ton in class, that way when we get to week three we have more of an understanding of how fiction pieces are written.

Strengths: Writing exercises forced the students to frequently generate content under different constraints that allowed exploration of the craft; workshops provided students both the skills to critically discern what makes a good short story (by evaluating their peers)  and the workshopped author meaningful feedback from a thoughtful readership.
Weaknesses: there wasnt enough discussion of plotting before tackling the full short story

The strengths of the course are definitely the feedback sessions with other students and the ability to read other student's work. You really don't learn from the professor, but rather from the other students in the class. If you are skeptical about how much you can actually formally improve in creative writing, don't be. You objectively will get much better at writing after this class.
The exercises and workshops were very fun and useful, and the class was very engaging overall. I would have liked to have more small group sessions with my classmates.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The requirement to have our mics always on over Zoom was really hard to get used to, but it actually turned out really well as we all got more comfortable with it
I think the weekly virtual office hours was helpful and online seminar time ran as well as it could.
We had our mics on and cameras on, which I thought worked really well.

Sharing the computer screen on zoom was a critical tool we used to read aloud and discuss student work. As a student shared their work aloud, listeners would comment in the chat on words and phrases that resonated, which was really helpful instantaneous reader-writer feedback. Also, virtual office hours allowed one on one feedback/conversation with the professor on our work. Finally, the virtual reading at the end of the semester allowed authors to invite many guests to hear the work shared allowed in a larger venue than they likely could have had on campus.
The only thing to improve is the time. The class is over 2 hours and it lends itself toward a lot of Zoom fatigue.
The workshop format worked well over Zoom. The small group sessions, office hours, and reading presentations were good ways for us to engage further in the course.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, because it is a great way to improve your fiction writing skills because of the weekly writing assignments which were really fun

Yes, definitely! Professor Gaige created a warm, respectful, and productive learning environment in which to praise and critique each other's writing, discuss what makes for persuasive storytelling, analyze exemplary works of short fiction, practice our own writing, and collaboratively grapple with some of the literary/personal challenges that confront writers.

I would! It's a good intro course. A lot of the students admitted had never written fiction before, which can be frustrating but was ultimately rewarding to get a variety of perspectives. Prof Gaige is a good lecturer and gives helpful feedback.

Yes. This course is literally incredibly, especially with Amity Gaige. It's amazing to be able to write your own short stores and Amity Gaige is so accomplished and talented but very humble and respectful of her students. This is an incredible class.

Yes! Even if you limited experience in creative writing or fiction specifically, this class is a really helpful space for breaking down blank-page anxieties, experimenting with technique and building up to two short stories that you can be proud of!

YES YES YES! You will definitely learn so much about creative writing. No matter how much you think you know, you will improve and understand many concepts. Be prepared to structure your time well because there is a lot of work that you have to each week (write 1 3-page short story, do ~2 15-20page readings, write 2-3 1-page critique letters, do line edits on ~30 pages worth of stories. 

But this heavy workload is what makes the class so meaningful and valuable to each author!
I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in writing fiction and/or who enjoys workshops.
